title: Miming won’t get you anywhere – Prof John Collins tells musicians
text:
Source: Ghana | Myjoyonline.com | Ernest Dela Aglanu (Twitter: @delaXdela / Instagram: citizendela) Date: 22-10-2015 Time: 09:10:59:pm Prof John Collins 
Prof John Collins, a Lecturer at the Music Department of the University of Ghana has cautioned Ghanaian musicians against miming their songs at shows. 
He warned that if musicians do not check the development, they won’t go anywhere with their music. 
The issue of Ghanaian musicians miming on stage seems to be one phenomenon that has no end in sight. Although some musicians, like Samini and Okyeame Kwame have reinvented themselves to do live performances, some are adamant. 
Commenting on the situation during an interview on Personality Profile on Joy FM with Lexis Bill Thursday, Prof John Collins said musicians miming is a big problem in Ghana. 
“I don’t think you can go anywhere if you have a band that mimes. I think it started with the burger highlife musicians and it continued with a lot of the hiplifers. I know some are now begging to perform live.” 
He cited that, for example, “If you go a programme in America or Europe and you put on your record on stage and mime to it, there is likely to be a riot [and] people will just throw their chairs at you. They will demand their money back because when they are going for a live show, they don’t imagine you can go to a show [where] people are miming.” 
Apart from the miming, the music professor expressed worry at the incorporation of “too much mechanics” in Ghanaian music today. 
He advised that musicians can combine live music like drums and the electronics to achieve good music. 
“In the West, a lot of people have reacted against the over computerisation of music. They want to have live music. I think you have to have a balance of these things,” Prof John Collins added.
